docs.lead_paragraph: Following is President Clinton's State of the Union address to Congress tonight, as recorded by The New York Times. The headings are from the original. Thank you very much. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Please be seated. Thank you. Thank you very much.

headline.main: President Clinton on State of Union: 'The Strongest It Has Ever Been'

docs.abstract: Text of Pres Clinton's State of Union message to Congress; photo of Clinton, and Vice Pres Al Gore and House Speaker J Dennis Hastert (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY baby boomers can vaguely recall the childhood bouts with croup or chicken pox that brought the friendly family doctor to the bedside. Now it is their parents who need bedside medical attention. And though it may seem the only place to find a doctor on a house call is a Norman Rockwell painting, a small but growing handful of Long Island doctors are reviving the practice.

headline.main: Sorry, but the Doctor Is Out (Now Making House Calls)

docs.abstract: Article on small but growing number of family doctors on Long Island who are reviving practice of making house calls, mostly to treat elderly patients; photos (M)
docs.snippet: MANY baby boomers can vaguely recall the childhood bouts with croup or chicken pox that brought the friendly family doctor to the bedside. Now it is their parents who need bedside medical attention.     And though it may seem the only place to find a...

docs.lead_paragraph: As insurance fraud cases go, the federal government's case against Dr. Niels H. Lauersen is far from typical. Dr. Lauersen, a well-known Manhattan gynecologist and fertility expert, did not deal with Medicare or Medicaid, the government insurance programs that often attract fraudulent billing schemes. And prosecutors acknowledge that unlike doctors in most medical fraud cases, who bill for procedures that never took place or for patients who do not exist, Dr. Lauersen treated real patients for real conditions, treatments they were desperately seeking.

headline.main: Fraud Case Underscores Debate on Paying for Infertility Care

docs.abstract: Health insurance fraud trial of Dr Nils H Lauersen, well-known Manhattan gynecologist and fertility expert, opens new territory for health fraud cases; Lauersen is accused of billing insurance companies for routine gynecological procedures to cover fertility surgeries for women who could not otherwise get pregnant; law enforcement officials say that over course of 10 years, Lauersen submitted hundreds of false bills amounting to roughly $4 million; photo (M)
